appTitle: Management Revision Quiz by Fathi Amzar

questions.question: Match each level of management with its main responsibility.
right: Perform assigned tasks
Make organization-wide decisions
Supervise non-managerial employees
Implement plans and supervise first-line managers

correctMatches.Middle managers: Implement plans and supervise first-line managers

questions.question: Match the management level with the correct example.
right: Supervisor
Chief Executive Officer (CEO)
Department manager
Sales assistant

questions.question: Arrange the levels of management from highest to lowest.
Match each management function with its description.
right: Monitoring performance and taking corrective action
Setting goals and strategies
Arranging tasks and resources
Motivating and directing employees

correctMatches.Controlling: Monitoring performance and taking corrective action

questions.question: Match the managerial role category with its examples.
right: Figurehead, Leader, Liaison
Monitor, Disseminator, Spokesperson
Entrepreneur, Disturbance handler, Negotiator

questions.question: Match the managerial skill with its meaning.
right: Ability to think analytically and see the organization as a whole
Job-specific knowledge and techniques
Ability to work well with others

correctMatches.Human skill: Ability to work well with others
correctMatches.Conceptual skill: Ability to think analytically and see the organization as a whole

questions.question: Match each managerial level with the MOST important skill.
right: Conceptual skill
Human skill
Technical skill

questions.question: Match the rewards and challenges of being a manager.
right: Reward
Reward
Challenge
Challenge

chapters.title: Chapter 2: Planning, Goal Setting & Decision Making

questions.question: Match each reason for planning with the correct explanation.
right: Helps employees stay focused and aligned with objectives
Helps managers anticipate change and prepare responses
Coordinates tasks to avoid repeating work and wasting resources
Creates benchmarks to compare actual performance with goals

correctMatches.Provides direction: Helps employees stay focused and aligned with objectives
correctMatches.Reduces uncertainty: Helps managers anticipate change and prepare responses
correctMatches.Minimizes waste and redundancy: Coordinates tasks to avoid repeating work and wasting resources
correctMatches.Sets standards for controlling: Creates benchmarks to compare actual performance with goals

questions.question: Match the term with the correct meaning.
right: Desired outcomes or targets
Documents outlining how goals will be met (resources, schedules, actions)

correctMatches.Plans: Documents outlining how goals will be met (resources, schedules, actions)

questions.question: Match each type of goals with the correct description.
right: Goals related to internal financial performance
Goals related to performance relative to external environment (competitors, market)
Official goals an organization says it wants stakeholders to believe
Goals actually pursued based on members’ actions and priorities

correctMatches.Financial goals: Goals related to internal financial performance
correctMatches.Strategic goals: Goals related to performance relative to external environment (competitors, market)
correctMatches.Stated goals: Official goals an organization says it wants stakeholders to believe
correctMatches.Real goals: Goals actually pursued based on members’ actions and priorities

questions.question: Match each type of plan with the correct clue/example style.
right: Broad plans for the entire organization (vision/mission)
Narrow plans for a specific area (e.g., training program)
Time frame beyond three years
Time frame one year or less

correctMatches.Strategic plans: Broad plans for the entire organization (vision/mission)
correctMatches.Operational plans: Narrow plans for a specific area (e.g., training program)
correctMatches.Short-term plans: Time frame one year or less

questions.question: Match each plan type with the best description.
right: Clearly defined and leaves no room for interpretation
Flexible guidelines that provide general direction
One-time plan designed for a unique situation
Ongoing plan used repeatedly (policies/procedures)

correctMatches.Specific plans: Clearly defined and leaves no room for interpretation
correctMatches.Directional plans: Flexible guidelines that provide general direction
correctMatches.Single-use plans: One-time plan designed for a unique situation

questions.question: Arrange the steps in goal setting in the correct order.
correctOrder: Determine the goals (measurable, specific, time frame)
Review results and adjust goals if needed

questions.question: Match the criteria of well-written goals with the correct meaning.
right: States results, not just activities
Can be quantified and tracked
Has a clear deadline
Difficult but realistic
Recorded so it becomes visible evidence
Shared with people who need to know

correctMatches.Written down: Recorded so it becomes visible evidence
correctMatches.Communicated: Shared with people who need to know

questions.question: Arrange the Decision-Making Process steps in the correct order.
Match each decision concept with the best description.
right: Logical and consistent choices to maximize value
Rational decisions limited by time, info, and human ability
Choosing a solution that is 'good enough'
Continuing a failing course because of past investment

correctMatches.Rational decision-making: Logical and consistent choices to maximize value
correctMatches.Bounded rationality: Rational decisions limited by time, info, and human ability
correctMatches.Satisficing: Choosing a solution that is 'good enough'
correctMatches.Escalation of commitment: Continuing a failing course because of past investment

questions.question: Match each approach with the correct clue.
right: Uses gut feeling and experience rather than lots of data
Uses facts, data, and research as the best available evidence

correctMatches.Intuitive decision-making: Uses gut feeling and experience rather than lots of data
correctMatches.Evidence-based management (EBMgt): Uses facts, data, and research as the best available evidence

questions.question: Decision biases (1/2): Match each bias with the best example.
right: Believing you will succeed easily despite little experience
Choosing a quick reward instead of a better long-term outcome
Relying too much on first information (initial price) when judging later
Only noticing info that supports your existing view
Looking only for evidence that supports your belief and ignoring opposites
Decision changes depending on how the same facts are presented

correctMatches.Overconfidence bias: Believing you will succeed easily despite little experience
correctMatches.Immediate gratification bias: Choosing a quick reward instead of a better long-term outcome
correctMatches.Anchoring effect: Relying too much on first information (initial price) when judging later
correctMatches.Selective perception bias: Only noticing info that supports your existing view
correctMatches.Confirmation bias: Looking only for evidence that supports your belief and ignoring opposites
correctMatches.Framing bias: Decision changes depending on how the same facts are presented

questions.question: Decision biases (2/2): Match each bias with the best example.
right: Overestimating something because it is recent/vivid in memory (news crash)
Judging likelihood based on stereotypes (suit = lawyer)
Believing random events have meaning (lucky item causes success)
Letting past spending affect current choices even though it can’t be recovered
Taking credit for success but blaming failure on external factors
After results, believing you 'knew it all along'

correctMatches.Availability bias: Overestimating something because it is recent/vivid in memory (news crash)
correctMatches.Representativeness bias: Judging likelihood based on stereotypes (suit = lawyer)
correctMatches.Randomness bias: Believing random events have meaning (lucky item causes success)
correctMatches.Sunk costs error: Letting past spending affect current choices even though it can’t be recovered
correctMatches.Self-serving bias: Taking credit for success but blaming failure on external factors
correctMatches.Hindsight bias: After results, believing you 'knew it all along'

chapters.title: Chapter 3: Designing Adaptive Organizations and Managing Change

questions.question: Match each key element of organizational design with its correct description.
right: Dividing work into separate tasks so individuals focus on specific activities
Grouping jobs based on functions, products, geography, process, or customers
Clear line of authority showing who reports to whom
Number of employees a manager can efficiently supervise
Degree to which decision-making is concentrated or spread out
Extent to which rules and procedures standardize jobs

correctMatches.Work specialization: Dividing work into separate tasks so individuals focus on specific activities
correctMatches.Departmentalization: Grouping jobs based on functions, products, geography, process, or customers
correctMatches.Chain of command: Clear line of authority showing who reports to whom
correctMatches.Span of control: Number of employees a manager can efficiently supervise
correctMatches.Centralization and decentralization: Degree to which decision-making is concentrated or spread out
correctMatches.Formalization: Extent to which rules and procedures standardize jobs

questions.question: Match each purpose of organizing with the correct explanation.
left: Divides work into jobs and departments
right: Breaks work into manageable tasks and departments
Clarifies who is responsible for each task
Ensures departments work together smoothly
Groups similar jobs for efficiency
Defines how individuals and groups interact
Clarifies who has authority and decision power
Distributes money, people, and equipment where needed

correctMatches.Divides work into jobs and departments: Breaks work into manageable tasks and departments
correctMatches.Assigns tasks and responsibilities: Clarifies who is responsible for each task
correctMatches.Establishes relationships: Defines how individuals and groups interact
correctMatches.Establishes formal lines of authority: Clarifies who has authority and decision power
correctMatches.Allocates organizational resources: Distributes money, people, and equipment where needed

questions.question: Match each type of departmentalization with the correct description.
right: Grouping jobs by functions such as HR, marketing, or finance
Grouping jobs based on product lines
Grouping jobs based on regions or locations
Grouping jobs based on stages of production or workflow
Grouping jobs based on different customer needs

correctMatches.Functional: Grouping jobs by functions such as HR, marketing, or finance
correctMatches.Product: Grouping jobs based on product lines
correctMatches.Geographical: Grouping jobs based on regions or locations
correctMatches.Process: Grouping jobs based on stages of production or workflow
correctMatches.Customer: Grouping jobs based on different customer needs

questions.question: Match each force of change with the correct example or explanation.
right: Company adopts a new approach to compete in the market
Hiring new employees or changing job roles
Introducing new machines or software
Employees’ values or motivation shift
Customers demand new or better products
New regulations force organizations to comply
Recession or economic growth affects business decisions
Rapid development of new digital tools

correctMatches.New organizational strategy: Company adopts a new approach to compete in the market
correctMatches.Change in workforce composition: Hiring new employees or changing job roles
correctMatches.Changing consumer needs: Customers demand new or better products
correctMatches.New governmental laws: New regulations force organizations to comply
correctMatches.Economic change: Recession or economic growth affects business decisions
correctMatches.Technological advancement: Rapid development of new digital tools

questions.question: Match each type of organizational change with its meaning.
right: Modification in how the organization competes
Changes in hierarchy, teams, or reporting lines
Adoption of new tools or methods
Changes in employee attitudes, skills, or behaviors

correctMatches.Strategy change: Modification in how the organization competes
correctMatches.Structure change: Changes in hierarchy, teams, or reporting lines
correctMatches.Technology change: Adoption of new tools or methods
correctMatches.People change: Changes in employee attitudes, skills, or behaviors

questions.question: Match each reason for resistance to change with the correct explanation.
left: Fear of losing status or benefits
Belief change is not in best interest
right: Employees feel anxious about the unknown
People prefer familiar routines
Employees worry about job position or rewards
Employees feel the change does not align with goals

correctMatches.Uncertainty and ambiguity: Employees feel anxious about the unknown
correctMatches.Fear of losing status or benefits: Employees worry about job position or rewards
correctMatches.Belief change is not in best interest: Employees feel the change does not align with goals

questions.question: Match each technique for reducing resistance to change with its description.
right: Explaining the need for change clearly to employees
Involving employees in the decision-making process
Providing training, counseling, and support
Offering something of value in exchange for cooperation
Influencing people indirectly or selectively presenting information
Using force, threats, or pressure to ensure compliance

correctMatches.Education and communication: Explaining the need for change clearly to employees
correctMatches.Participation: Involving employees in the decision-making process
correctMatches.Negotiation: Offering something of value in exchange for cooperation
correctMatches.Manipulation and co-optation: Influencing people indirectly or selectively presenting information
correctMatches.Coercion: Using force, threats, or pressure to ensure compliance
